On 12/9/05, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> Simon Chappell wrote:
>
> Si=
mon,
>
> I'm intrigued.  On many of my projects, I have a single suite of f=
ast
> tests that cover all the classes in my project; no need for a suite f=
or
> each class.  I find that this often allows me to catch accidental
> de=
pendencies, and also allows me to have the structure of my tests not
> be r=
igidly isomorphic to the structure of my code.  Would this strategy
> work =
on your projects?
>
>     David Saff
>

This is similiar to my experience. =
 I have a TestAll that dynamically
finds all test cases and assembles the s=
uite, no hand coded suites
needed.  There are some tests in there that are =
slower and could
(should) probably be moved to a seperater, longer build - =
it just
hasn't gotten painful enough for me to do it.

Also, to respond to =
"I think that working on one object and one test
at a time is enough".  I f=
ind that doesn't really work when you want
to do larger automated refactori=
ngs - ie rename class/public
method/etc.  With a fast running local test su=
ites, those types of
changes are easy and simple.  Not sure how well that w=
ould work out
when you have to wait for the build to run to test it.

- Rob=
